title: Trump on election-related hacking: 'I think it was Russia'

text:
Share on Facebook Share on Twitter 
Donald Trump on Wednesday said he accepts the intelligence community’s conclusion that Russia was behind the cyberattacks on Democratic Party officials that disrupted the presidential election, shifting his position after he spent weeks publicly questioning that finding. 
“As far as hacking, I think it was Russia,” the president-elect said at a highly-anticipated press conference in New York, his first since last July. By Louis Nelson Story Continued Below 
Trump was quick, though, to downplay Russia’s suspected attempt to meddle in the election, saying, “I also think we also get hacked by other countries, and other people.” He then blamed the Democratic National Committee for being “totally open to be hacked.” 
Trump did not say whether or not he also accepts intelligence officials’ belief that Russia hacked into the emails of the DNC and Hillary Clinton’s campaign chairman, John Podesta, specifically to undermine the election and tilt it in favor of Trump. The hacks resulted in thousands of private emails being published on the website WikiLeaks, repeatedly embarrassing the Clinton campaign. 
Trump spent weeks refusing to accept the intelligence community’s conclusions on Russia’s role in the hacking, to the dismay of his critics and some members of his own party who fear Russia’s aggression.
